title: Tesco loses Supreme Court legal battle over plans to ‘fire and rehire’ distribution workers
text:
By Jessica Clark
Updated: 22:01 BST, 12 September 2024
Tesco has lost a Supreme Court battle with the retail workers union over ‘fire and rehire’ plans.
The supermarket giant faced legal action by the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers (Usdaw) after it tried to sack distribution centre staff and rehire them on lower pay in 2021.
After the High Court ruled in the union’s favour in 2022, the supermarket giant successfully appealed against the decision the same year.
But the Supreme Court yesterday ruled Tesco should be blocked from dismissing the staff.
Court fight: Tesco faced legal action by the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers (Usdaw) after it tried to sack distribution centre staff and rehire them on lower pay in 2021
It comes as Labour plots workers’ rights reforms that will ban fire and rehire policies and zero-hour contracts.
It is feared the new rules facing business – alongside the prospect of higher taxes – will put companies off hiring staff.
The row broke out after Tesco planned to close some distribution centres in 2007, offering staff a higher salary – which was known as ‘retained pay’ – for them to relocate.
In 2021, the grocer tried to end ‘retained pay’ and told staff they would remove it in return for a lump sum payment, or their contracts would be terminated and reoffered on the same terms at a lower salary.
Usdaw argued that the higher salary was described as permanent in the contracts and could not be removed.
Tesco argued that it was using a ‘contractual mechanism’ open to employers.
But the Supreme Court judgment said was ‘inconceivable’ that ‘Tesco would retain a unilateral right to terminate the contracts of employees in order to bring retained pay to an end whenever it suited Tesco’s business purposes to do so’.
‘That would have been viewed, objectively, as unrealistic and as flouting industrial common sense by both sides,’ it said.
Paddy Lillis, Usdaw general secretary, said: ‘These tactics have no place in industrial relations, so we felt we had to act to protect those concerned.’
Tesco accepted the ruling, adding: ‘Today’s judgment relates to a dispute brought on behalf of a very small number of colleagues in our UK distribution network who receive a supplement to their pay.’
The ‘vast majority’ of distribution staff do not receive the top-up, it said.
‘In 2021, we took the decision to phase it out. We made a competitive offer at that time and many of them chose to accept this.
‘Our aim has always been to engage constructively with Usdaw and the small number of colleagues affected.’

title: NH Investment selected as UN GCF manager
text:
Banking & Finance
NH Investment selected as UN GCF manager
It's the first Asian securities firm chosen to manage $200 mn in the UN-affiliated GCF's Climate Tech Fund
By 4 HOURS AGO
1 Min read
Most Read
South Korea's NH Investment & Securities announced on Thursday that it was selected as the first Asian securities firm to manage the Climate Tech Fund under the Green Climate Fund (GCF), affiliated with the UN.
The GCF, established to support greenhouse gas reduction funding in developing countries, aims to expand participation in climate projects in five Southeast Asian countries (Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, Cambodia, and Laos) through this program.
The fund managed by NH Investment & Securities will be worth $200 million.
NH Investment & Securities' Carbon Finance Division will identify companies to invest in, while the Singapore-based NH Absolute Return Partners will establish and manage the fund.

title: Qué dijo Valentín Gómez luego de que se caiga la compra del City Group: "Es algo duro, pero..." - MDZ Online
text: El defensor central de 21 años aterrizó en Ezeiza luego de su viaje a Palermo, Italia. En su retorno al país, se refirió al motivo por el que se cayó la compra de su pase. Luego de que la venta de Valentín Gómez al City Group quedará truncada debido a que al jugador le detectaron un síndrome meniscal en la rodilla izquierda (en la revisión médica realizada en Palermo, Italia), el futbolista de 21 años, aterrizó en el aeropuerto de Ezeiza. Allí lo esperaban los medios de comunicación, quienes pudieron obtener algunas declaraciones del hombre que viene de tener una gran performance con la camiseta de Vélez. “Es algo duro, pero lo importante es que mi rodilla está bien y estoy listo para jugar”, manifestó. Mirá el video “Salió una lesión que había tenido en el menisco en 2021, que fue muy chiquita y eso fue lo que saltó en el estudio médico. Jugué todos los partidos sin ningún tipo de dolencia así que estoy bien”, comenzó el futbolista ni bien llegó a nuestro país tras su viaje a Italia. Sobre su futuro, no dudó en asegurar que le gustaría emigrar al Millonario: "Lo tengo que ver, pero mi idea es dar un paso en mi carrera. Si es en River , mejor, pero si sigo en Vélez voy a seguir con las mismas ganas de siempre. Voy a seguir jugando igual que siempre, sin ningún tipo de molestias. Obvio que me gustaría jugar en River, pero Vélez también es un club grande de la Argentina”. Gómez suma un total de 87 partidos con la camiseta de Vélez y en su contrato, el cual vence en diciembre del 2026, posee una cláusula de recisión de 10 millones de dólares. El Millonario buscará negociar con el Fortín por una suma menor a la que establece su vínculo.
